factoid: Rostóv and "Uncle" talked after supper over cherry brandy.
Rostóv and "Uncle" talked about past hunts.
Rostóv and "Uncle" talked about future hunts.
Rostóv and "Uncle" talked about Rugáy and Ilágin’s dogs.
Natásha sat upright on the sofa.
Natásha listened with sparkling eyes.
Natásha tried several times to wake Pétya so that he might eat something.
Pétya muttered incoherent words without waking up.
Natásha felt lighthearted and happy in the novel surroundings.
Natásha feared that a trap would come for her too soon.
Uncle said that he is finishing his days.
Uncle said that death will come.
Uncle said that nothing will remain.
Uncle questioned why harm anyone.
Uncle’s face was significant and handsome while he was speaking.
Rostóv recalled the good things he had heard about Uncle from his father.
Rostóv recalled the good things he had heard about Uncle from the neighbors.
Uncle had the reputation of being the most honorable cranks in the province.
Uncle had the reputation of being the most disinterested cranks in the province.
People called Uncle to decide family disputes.
People chose Uncle as executor.
People confided secrets to Uncle.
People elected Uncle to be a justice.
People elected Uncle to other posts.
Uncle persistently refused public appointments.
Uncle passed autumn and spring in the fields on his bay gelding.
Uncle sat at home in winter.
Uncle lay in his overgrown garden in summer.
Someone asked Uncle why he didn't enter the service.
Uncle replied that he had once entered but gave it up.
Uncle said he was not fit for the service.
Uncle said he couldn't make head or tail of it.
Uncle said he didn't have enough brains for it.
Uncle said hunting is another matter.
Uncle shouted to open the door.
Uncle asked why the door had been shut.
The door at the end of the passage led to the huntsmen’s room.
The huntsmen’s room was called the room for the hunt servants.
A rapid patter of bare feet was heard.
An unseen hand opened the door into the huntsmen’s room.
Clear sounds of a balaláyka came from the huntsmen’s room.
Someone who was evidently a master of the art was playing the balaláyka.
Natásha had been listening to those strains for some time.
Natásha went out into the passage to hear better.
Uncle identified Mítka as his coachman.
Uncle said he had gotten Mítka a good balaláyka.
Uncle expressed fondness for the balaláyka.
It was custom for Mítka to play the balaláyka in the huntsmen’s room when Uncle returned from the chase.
Uncle was fond of such music.
Nicholas said "How good! Really very good!" with unintentional superciliousness.
Nicholas was ashamed to confess that the sounds pleased him very much.
Natásha reproachfully asked "Very good?"
Natásha noticed her brother’s tone.
Natásha said the song was simply delicious.
Uncle’s pickled mushrooms had seemed to Natásha the best in the world.
Uncle’s honey had seemed to Natásha the best in the world.
Uncle’s cherry brandy had seemed to Natásha the best in the world.
The song seemed to Natásha the acme of musical delight.
Natásha cried "More, please, more!" at the door as soon as the balaláyka ceased.
Mítka tuned up afresh.
Mítka recommenced thrumming the balaláyka to the air of My Lady with trills and variations.
Uncle sat listening.
Uncle slightly smiled.
Uncle had his head on one side.
The air was repeated a hundred times.
The balaláyka was retuned several times.
The same notes were thrummed again.
The listeners did not grow weary of it.
The listeners wished to hear it again and again.
Anísya Fëdorovna came in.
Anísya leaned her portly person against the doorpost.
Anísya asked Natásha "You like listening?"
Anísya smiled extremely like Uncle’s.
Anísya said "That’s a good player …"
Uncle said "He doesn’t play that part right!" with an energetic gesture.
Uncle said "Here he ought to burst out—come on!—ought to burst out."
Natásha asked "Do you play then?"
Uncle did not answer.
Uncle smiled.
Uncle told Anísya to go and see if the strings of his guitar are all right.
Uncle said he hadn't touched his guitar for a long time.
Uncle said he had given it up.
